Governor says longer living state workers will drive pension costs up $1.2 billion per year/Sacto Bee

February 7th, 2014

FYI

http://www.sacbee.com/2014/02/05/6131804/read-jerry-browns-letter-calling.html

“Gov. Jerry Brown, citing statistics showing government employees are living longer and driving up pension costs, has challenged CalPERS to increase employers’ contribution to the fund instead of following a staff recommendation to delay raising rates for two years.  Waiting, he says, merely adds to the funds debt.”

Blog:

“Employers’ contribution” would translate to less services for the taxpayer to cover the increased costs.

A better method is for “users” i.e., state employees, to pay more for their own retirement plans, in form of an IRA or 401K similar to the private sector citizen that must save and/or invest for retirement without a defined benefit guarantee.  The system is on its way to becoming unsustainable.  Then what?

Government reform group launches public pension database/Sacramento Bee

February 6th, 2014

FYI   http://www.sacbee.com/2014/02/04/6125543/government-reform-group-launches.html

“A conservative Southern California group has launched a public pension database that includes retiree’s names, their annual pension payments, years of service, last employer and year of retirement.”

“A center press release announcing the database notes that nearly 100 former government employees received a quarter-million dollars or more in annual pension payments in 2012, that more than 1700 CalPERS pensioners received at least $150,000 from the fund and that California’s two university systems paid 27,115 retired public employees pensions of $100,000 or more.”

http://transparentcalifornia.com/

Blog:

Taxpayers need to know how government pensions/wages have escalated in the past ten years far above the average salaries/pensions in the private sector of our state. Higher benefit levels once made sense when government salaries were far below private-sector wages but now, many, if not most, government workers earn significantly higher salaries and benefits most especially in lower income counties like Riverside.  It is a very serious matter when the average California Public Employees’ Retirement System pension for those who worked at least 30 years is now greater than the average household income in California.

Cash For College/Financial Aid Workshop - Perris High School/Perris

January 16th, 2014

FYI for Students/Parents

Assemblymember Jose Medina invites you to attend this important educational workshop.

Financial Aid Counselors will be on site to help with the paperwork and assist students and parents.  This is also a great opportunity to discuss legislation on this and any other topic.

Location:  Perris High School - 175 East Nuevo Road - Perris, CA  92570

When:       Thursday, January 30th - 6:00PM - 8:00PM

For more info, please call the District Office @ 951-369-6644

Blog:

Cal Grants and Middle Class Scholarships are only available by filling out the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) or the CA Dream Act Application. Grants and Scholarships are not available unless you fill out the application and meet the March 2, 2014 deadline.

Bypass for Sunset underpass too costly/Press Enterprise

January 16th, 2014

FYI

http://www.pe.com/local-news/riverside-county/the-pass/the-pass-headlines-index/20140115-banning-bypass-route-idea-scuttled-during-underpass-project.ece

“Banning won’t be able to build a temporary east-west bypass road to help divert traffic during Sunset Avenue railroad underpass construction, after all.”

“Public Works director Duane Burk told the City Council that the cost of the project has doubled to $2 million because petroleum and gas transmission lines would need to be protected and creek crossings modified along the route of the planned Westward Avenue.”

“MSJC, San Gorgonio campus, at the southeast corner, is notifying students and staff by email about the upcoming construction and detours.”  The campus had 955 students attending classes at various times/days in academic year 2012-13.  There are nearly 40 employees.”

Blog:

Having “nearly 40 employees” at the campus sounds employee heavy for 955 student head count (not FTES). Serving students in this area of the district is important, however duplication of administrative services is costly and probably not the most efficient use of taxpayer dollars.

Governor’s Proposed 2014-14 Budget

January 9th, 2014

FYI  See Pages 34-41 for California Community Colleges and Higher Ed

http://www.aroundthecapitol.com/docs/CAbudget2014.pdf

Highlights:

*   a 0.86% cost of living adjustment (48.5 million).

*  3% enrollment growth/restoration ($155.2 million), with a direction to the Board of Governors to adopt a growth formula that “gives priority to districts identified as having the greatest unmet need in adequately serving their community’s higher educational needs.”

*  $100 million augmentation for continued expansion of the Student Success/Support Program.

*  $100 million “to close achievement gaps in access/achievement in underrepresented student groups.

*  $87.5 million for scheduled maintenance (one time funds).

*  $592.4 million to eliminate all cash deferrals.

*  $1.1 million additional staffing for the Chancellor’s Office.

*  $50 million for higher education innovations incentive award program for UC/CSU/CCC.

Blog:

A priority restoration growth factor for community college district’s with the lowest college going/participation rate is imperative for MSJC to make any progress in this metric.  May-be a new funding formula should have a “catch up” factor to accelerate to the state average participation rate.  It would appear that our Administration/CBO should be directed by the BOT to lobby for such as the Board of Governors review and determine policy for a new funding formula.
